articles.title: UK expected to reduce amount of steel it allows in tariff-free
articles.summary:
Change being considered amid global glut driven by supplies from China along with a rise in protectionism

The UK is expected to reduce the amount of foreign steel it allows in tariff-free, as the government looks to protect its domestic industry amid a global glut and a rise in protectionism.

Ministers are considering changing the quota system that allows a quantity of the metal to be imported before imposing a 25% levy on anything above that level.

Shift in relations and unpredictability of Donald Trump make it ‘risky to store so much gold in the US’, say experts

Germany is facing calls to withdraw its billions of euros’ worth of gold from US vaults, spurred on by the shift in transatlantic relations and the unpredictability of Donald Trump.

Germany holds the world’s second biggest national gold reserves after the US, of which approximately €164bn (£122bn) worth – 1,236 tonnes – is stored in New York.

Редакция отмечает, что сокращения в камере и времени работы от батареи могут быть слишком ощутимыми для большинства пользователей. Таким образом, устройство сводит суть iPhone к абсолютным основам в премиальном корпусе, заставляя задуматься о цене за легкость.
articles.original_description:
Ultra-slim and light smartphone feels special, but cuts to camera and battery may be too hard to ignore for most

The iPhone Air is a technical and design marvel that asks: how much are you willing to give up for a lightweight and ultra-slender profile?

Beyond the obvious engineering effort that has gone into creating one of the slimmest phones ever made, the Air is a reductive exercise that boils down the iPhone into the absolute essentials in a premium body.

articles.summary: Метеорологическая служба Великобритании (Met Office) прогнозирует, что 2025 год станет самым тёплым с начала ведения метеонаблюдений. Научный консультант по климату предупреждает, что это свидетельствует о продолжении тренда на глобальное потепление.
articles.original_description: The Met Office says that 2025 is likely to be the UK's hottest year since records began.

articles.title: 'Year of octopus' declared after warmer seas lead to record UK numbers
articles.summary: Год осьминога объявлен в Великобритании после рекордного увеличения численности этих моллюсков, вызванного потеплением моря. По данным Wildlife Trusts, количество наблюдений достигло максимума с 1950 года.
articles.original_description: The Wildlife Trusts say its is 'flabbergasted' by the sighting of the highest number of octopuses since 1950

articles.title: Hen cages and pig farrowing crates face ban
articles.summary: Правительство Великобритании планирует запретить клетки для кур и станки для опороса свиней в рамках масштабной реформы благосостояния животных. Эта инициатива названа крупнейшими изменениями в этой области за последнее поколение.
articles.original_description: The government says its animal welfare strategy will bring "the biggest reforms in a generation".

articles.title: Government rolls back nature protections to boost housing
articles.summary: Правительство отменило часть мер по охране природы в рамках ключевой политики в области биоразнообразия, чтобы стимулировать строительство жилья. Критики опасаются, что эти изменения могут замедлить восстановление природных экосистем.
articles.original_description: Critics say government changes to a flagship biodiversity policy could stall nature recovery.

articles.title: Spain's commitment to renewable energy may be in doubt
articles.summary: Правящая в Испании партия ослаблена политически, что ставит под сомнение её приверженность развитию возобновляемой энергетики. Оппозиция выступает за увеличение использования ископаемого топлива, что может повлиять на энергетическую политику страны.
articles.original_description: The current government is politically weakened and the opposition wants more use of fossil fuels.

articles.title: Cats became our companions much later than you think
articles.summary: Кошки стали домашними животными значительно позже, чем считалось ранее. Исследования показывают, что их приручение произошло не в Древнем Египте, а в более поздний период, когда они сами постепенно начали селиться рядом с людьми.
articles.original_description: In true feline style, cats took their time in deciding when and where to join us on the sofa.

articles.title: Brazil's Amazon rainforest at risk as key protection under threat
articles.summary: Фермеры Бразилии требуют отмены запрета на выращивание сои на вырубленных участках Амазонии, что может привести к ускорению обезлесения. Критики предупреждают, что отмена ограничений поставит под угрозу усилия по охране крупнейшего в мире тропического леса.
articles.original_description: Brazilian farmers want to end a ban on planting soya on cleared land, which critics say would spur deforestation.

articles.title: Landmark deal to cut global shipping emissions in tatters after US pressure
articles.summary: План сокращения выбросов в глобальном судоходстве оказался под угрозой из-за вмешательства президента Трампа, который назвал соглашение «экологической афёрой». Под давлением США переговоры по климатическому договору были сорваны.
articles.original_description: President Trump intervened in the talks calling the deal a "green scam".

articles.title: Australia's rainforests are releasing more carbon than they absorb, warn scientists
articles.summary: Учёные предупреждают, что тропические леса Австралии впервые в мире начали выделять больше углерода, чем поглощать. Это тревожное изменение связано с влиянием климатических изменений и увеличением частоты экстремальных погодных явлений.
articles.original_description: Australia's rainforests are the first in the world to make the "concerning" switch, say scientists.

articles.title: Pictured: Winning entries for Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2025
articles.summary: Южноафриканский фотограф Вим ван ден Хевер стал победителем конкурса Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2025, завоевав главный приз своей работой. В число победителей также вошли авторы лучших снимков дикой природы со всего мира.
articles.original_description: South African photographer Wim van den Heever takes the main prize for his shot

articles.title: Sonic Booms and Seismic Waves Can Reveal Where Space Junk Crash-Lands

Вибрации и акустические ударные волны от сгорающих обломков позволяют точно определять место их падения. Эта технология поможет заранее предупреждать людей о потенциальных опасностях.
articles.original_description: The sensors used to listen for earthquakes could help protect people from the hazards created by falling spacecraft.

articles.title: Filoplumes Are Nature’s Super Feather

articles.original_description: Filoplumes may be tiny, but these hairlike feathers enable nonstop flights that span thousands of miles.

articles.title: A Bite-Size Column About Delight and Wonder in Science
articles.summary: В колонке Trilobites репортёры делятся с читателями последними научными открытиями — от необычных дружеских связей между животными разных видов до находок древних окаменелостей. Цель публикаций — рассказывать о науке увлекательно и понятно, вызывая удивление и радость познания.
articles.original_description: In Trilobites, reporters aim to share new findings in the science world, be it interspecies friendships or discoveries of ancient fossils.

articles.title: Cows Use Tools, Too, New Study Finds
articles.summary: A pet cow named Veronika can scratch her own back with a broom — the first scientifically documented case of tool use in cows, researchers say.

articles.title: If the Volcanic Eruption Doesn’t Scare You, the Mudflow Should

articles.original_description: A professor at the University of California, Santa Cruz, he was a key contributor to a landmark paper that laid out how the universe came to look like it does today.

articles.title: Edith Flanigen, Award-Winning Research Chemist, Dies at 96
articles.summary: She and her staff at Union Carbide created synthetic materials that improved various industrial processes, including purifying water. She also developed a way to make emeralds.
articles.original_description: She and her staff at Union Carbide created synthetic materials that improved various industrial processes, including purifying water. She also developed a way to make emeralds.

articles.title: Pedro Sanchez, Who Helped Feed the Developing World, Dies at 85

articles.title: Louis E. Brus, Nobel Laureate Who Illuminated the Nanoworld, Dies at 82

articles.title: Vaccine Panel Chair Says Polio and Other Shots Should Be Optional, Rejecting Decades of Science

Он предложил сделать вакцинацию необязательной, что противоречит многолетним научным данным о её эффективности для общественного здоровья.
articles.original_description: Dr. Kirk Milhoan, a pediatric cardiologist who leads the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, said a person’s right to refuse a vaccine outweighed concerns about illness or death from infectious diseases.

articles.title: Increased Scrutiny Leads to an Improved Organ Transplant System

articles.title: An Antarctic Mission to Recover a Robot’s Data

articles.title: RFK Jr. Plan to Test a Vaccine in West African Babies Is Blocked

articles.title: Energy Dept. Says It Is Canceling $30 Billion in Clean Energy Loans
articles.summary: Министерство энергетики США отменило выдачу кредитов на чистую энергетику на сумму 30 миллиардов долларов. Это решение стало частью резкого изменения энергетической политики при администрации президента Трампа. Многие из этих отмен были известны ранее, но официальное объявление подчеркнуло сдвиг приоритетов ведомства.
articles.original_description: Many of the cancellations had been known for months, but the announcement underscored the drastic change in the energy landscape under President Trump.

articles.title: Trump Administration Cuts Off Funding for Fetal Tissue Research. Again.

articles.original_description: The prohibition halts support for projects both inside and outside the N.I.H. President Biden had restored funding after an earlier ban by President Trump during his first term.

Проект нацелен на обслуживание государственных структур, бизнеса и центров обработки данных, что ознаменует выход на рынок спутниковых группировок, где доминирует SpaceX.

articles.title: This small soil upgrade cut locust damage and doubled yields
articles.summary: Locust swarms can wipe out crops across entire regions, threatening food supplies and livelihoods. Now, scientists working with farmers in Senegal have shown that improving soil health can dramatically reduce locust damage. By enriching soil with nitrogen, crops become less appealing to the insects, leading to fewer locusts, less plant damage, and harvests that doubled in size.

articles.title: Brain waves could help paralyzed patients move again
articles.summary: People with spinal cord injuries often lose movement even though their brains still send the right signals. Researchers tested whether EEG brain scans could capture those signals and reroute them to spinal stimulators. The system can detect when a patient is trying to move, though finer control remains a challenge. Scientists hope future improvements could turn intention into action.

articles.title: The hidden health impact of growing up with ADHD traits
articles.summary: A large, decades-long study suggests that signs of ADHD in childhood may have consequences that extend well beyond school and behavior. Researchers followed nearly 11,000 people from childhood into midlife and found that those with strong ADHD traits at age 10 were more likely to experience multiple physical health problems and health-related disability by their mid-40s.

articles.title: A stiffening colon may be fueling cancer in younger adults
articles.summary: Chronic inflammation may be quietly reshaping the colon and making it more vulnerable to early-onset colorectal cancer. Scientists found that colon tissue in younger patients was stiffer, even in areas that appeared healthy, suggesting these changes may happen before cancer develops. Lab experiments showed that cancer cells grow faster in rigid environments.

articles.title: A hidden immune loop may drive dangerous inflammation with age
articles.summary: Aging immune cells may be sabotaging the body from within. Researchers found that macrophages produce a protein that locks them into a chronic inflammatory state, making infections like sepsis more deadly in older adults. Turning off this signal reduced inflammation and improved survival in older models. The findings hint at future treatments that could dial back harmful immune overreactions.

articles.summary: A groundbreaking new radio image reveals the Milky Way in more detail than ever before, using low-frequency radio “colors” to map the galaxy’s hidden structures. The image is sharper, deeper, and wider than anything previously released, uncovering both star-forming regions and the remains of ancient stellar explosions. articles.title: Astronomers found a black hole growing way too fast
articles.summary: Astronomers have spotted a rare, rule-breaking quasar in the early Universe that appears to be growing its central black hole at an astonishing pace. Observations show the black hole is devouring matter far faster than theory says it should—about 13 times the usual “speed limit”—while simultaneously blasting out bright X-rays and launching a powerful radio jet. This surprising combination wasn’t supposed to happen, according to many models, and suggests scientists may be catching the black hole

articles.title: New catalyst makes plastic upcycling 10x more efficient than platinum
articles.summary: Scientists are finding new ways to replace expensive, scarce platinum catalysts with something far more abundant: tungsten carbide. By carefully controlling how tungsten carbide’s atoms are arranged at extremely high temperatures, researchers discovered a specific form that can rival platinum in key chemical reactions, including turning carbon dioxide into useful fuels and chemicals. Even more promising, the same material proved dramatically better at breaking down plastic waste, outperforming p

articles.title: Ancient giant kangaroos could hop after all
articles.summary: Giant kangaroos that lived during the Ice Age may not have been as slow and grounded as once believed. A new study finds their leg bones and tendons were likely strong enough to support hopping, despite their massive size. Rather than traveling this way all the time, these animals may have relied on short bursts of hopping. This ability could have played a key role in escaping predators.

articles.title: Chemotherapy rewires gut bacteria to block metastasis
articles.summary: Chemotherapy’s gut damage turns out to have a surprising upside. By changing nutrient availability in the intestine, it alters gut bacteria and increases levels of a microbial molecule that travels to the bone marrow. This signal reshapes immune cell production, strengthening anti-cancer defenses and making metastatic sites harder for tumors to colonize. Patient data suggest this immune rewiring is linked to better survival.

articles.title: How type 2 diabetes quietly damages blood vessels
articles.summary: Type 2 diabetes becomes more dangerous to the heart the longer a person has it. Researchers found that after several years, red blood cells can begin interfering with healthy blood vessel function. This harmful shift was not present in newly diagnosed patients but emerged over time. A small molecule inside blood cells may help flag rising cardiovascular risk early.

articles.title: A blood test could reveal Crohn’s disease years before symptoms
articles.summary: Ученые разработали анализ крови, способный выявить болезнь Крона за годы до появления симптомов. Тест обнаруживает специфический иммунный ответ на кишечные бактерии, который был выявлен у здоровых родственников пациентов. Это открытие открывает перспективы для ранней диагностики и профилактики заболевания.
articles.original_description: A new blood test may reveal Crohn’s disease years before symptoms begin. The test detects an unusual immune response to gut bacteria in people who later develop the condition. By studying healthy relatives of Crohn’s patients, researchers identified early warning signals long in advance. The findings raise hope for earlier diagnosis and future prevention.

articles.title: The genetic advantage that helps some people stay sharp for life
articles.summary: A new study reveals that super agers over 80 have a distinct genetic edge. They are much less likely to carry the gene most associated with Alzheimer’s risk, even when compared with other healthy seniors. Researchers also found higher levels of a protective gene variant in this group. Together, the findings help explain why some people age with remarkably youthful minds.

articles.title: Why some people get bad colds and others don’t
articles.summary: Scientists found that nasal cells act as a first line of defense against the common cold, working together to block rhinovirus soon after infection. A fast antiviral response can stop the virus before symptoms appear. If that response is weakened or delayed, the virus spreads and causes inflammation and breathing problems. The study highlights why the body’s reaction matters more than the virus alone.

articles.title: A common vitamin could influence bathroom frequency
articles.summary: Scientists studying genetic data from over a quarter million people have uncovered new clues about what controls how fast the gut moves. They identified multiple DNA regions linked to bowel movement frequency, confirming known gut pathways and revealing new ones. The biggest surprise was a strong connection to vitamin B1, a common nutrient not usually linked to digestion.

articles.title: Scientists ranked monogamy across mammals and humans stand out
articles.summary: A new study suggests humans belong in an elite “league of monogamy,” ranking closer to beavers and meerkats than to chimpanzees. By comparing full and half siblings across species and human cultures, researchers found that long-term pair bonding is unusually common in our species. Even societies that permit polygamy show far more monogamy than most mammals. This rare evolutionary shift may have played a key role in human social success.

articles.title: A brain glitch may explain why some people hear voices
articles.summary: Новое исследование показывает, что галлюцинации при шизофрении могут возникать из-за сбоя в работе мозга, который принимает внутренние мысли за внешние голоса. Вместо нормального подавления активности при собственном внутреннем речи, мозг таких людей реагирует так, будто звук исходит от другого человека. Это открытие может помочь в разработке ранних методов диагностики психоза.
articles.original_description: New research suggests that auditory hallucinations in schizophrenia may come from a brain glitch that confuses inner thoughts for external voices. Normally, the brain predicts the sound of its own inner speech and tones down its response. But in people hearing voices, brain activity ramps up instead, as if the voice belongs to someone else. The discovery could help scientists develop early warning signs for psychosis.

articles.title: The bottled water everyone trusts may be the riskiest
articles.summary: In Guatemala’s Western Highlands, researchers found that the drinking water people trust most may actually be the riskiest. Bottled water from refillable jugs—seen as the safest choice—was frequently contaminated with harmful bacteria, while protected municipal wells were the cleanest.

articles.title: This new antibody may stop one of the deadliest breast cancers
articles.summary: Researchers have identified a promising new weapon against triple-negative breast cancer, one of the most aggressive forms of the disease. An experimental antibody targets a protein that fuels tumor growth and shuts down immune defenses, effectively turning the immune system back on. In early tests, the treatment slowed tumor growth, reduced lung metastases, and destroyed chemotherapy-resistant cancer cells.

articles.title: The place that stayed with me: on a wild, misty river I learned I have the strength for almost anything
articles.summary:
At first Stephanie Wood felt out of her depth rafting the Franklin, but by the end, a world of new possibilities had opened up

I am old, I am unfit for this project and I am colder than hell frozen over but I am also stuck. A helicopter will not winch me out because my only injuries are the agonies of dodgy hips, screaming arm muscles and deeply wounded pride.

articles.title: From Attenborough’s gorilla mayhem to TV’s first gay kiss: the 100 biggest moments from a century of television
articles.summary:
The moon landing! Royal weddings! Janet Jackson’s $550,000 nipple! As television turns 100, we charts its journey from terrifyingly dangerous to the thing that unites us

1: 1926 On 26 January John Logie Baird gives the first public demonstration of television to members of the Royal Institution, from his lab in Soho. The subject of the demonstration was Stooky Bill, Baird’s ventriloquist dummy, because the lighting generated too much heat for a human to bear.
